head.title: Serious Science At a New Museum

hedline.hl1: Serious Science At a New Museum

abstract.p: Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Sciences, one of Washington's newest museums, takes serious approach to science with exhibits featuring huge plasma and LCD screens, computer-based intractive learning stations and numerous models and maps; museum has attracted more than 15,000 visitors since opening in April, mainly between ages of 22 and 45; photo (S)

block.p: At one of Washington's newest museums, the Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Sciences, science makes a fashion statement. In one of the most popular exhibits, visitors swab their cheek to get a cell sample, then perform a few simple steps that let them take home their very own DNA necklaces.

But the Koshland has a more serious purpose, too: exploring scientific issues behind national public policy decisions. With huge plasma and LCD screens, computer-based interactive learning stations, and numerous models and maps, it offers a high-tech, hands-on look at global warming, DNA and criminal forensics. Unlike many science museums that aim their message at children, the Koshland takes an adult approach.

But the Koshland has a more serious purpose, too: exploring scientific issues behind national public policy decisions. With huge plasma and LCD screens, computer-based interactive learning stations, and numerous models and maps, it offers a high-tech, hands-on look at global warming, DNA and criminal forensics. Unlike many science museums that aim their message at children, the Koshland takes an adult approach.

Since the museum opened in April, it has attracted more than 15,000 visitors, mainly between the ages of 22 and 45, said Patrice Legro, the museum's director, a demographic that she says reflects the sophistication of the exhibits. One such example is an interactive global climate map -- mobile plasma screens that glide across a timeline of the past century. The exhibit shows local temperature changes throughout the world since 1900 and extrapolates through 2100.

On weekends, a varying schedule of demonstrations allows visitors to examine their own pores using a digital microscope, for example, or simulate the effects of burning fossil fuels just by breathing.

The museum, at Sixth and E Streets NW near the National Mall, is open daily except Tuesday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., with the last admission at 5 p.m.; admission, $5. Information: (888) 567-4526; www.koshland-science-museum.org.
